unnormalised: So, I was just at Crawford Market in Mumbai yesterday, and the price differences are WILD. I wanted to buy some dry fruits for Diwali, and the rates quoted by the first shopkeeper were like, Rs. 800/kg for almonds, and Rs. 600/kg for cashews. I thought that was a bit steep. Especially since last year it was around ₹650 for almonds.
normalised: So, I was just at Crawford Market in Mumbai yesterday, and the price differences are wild. I wanted to buy some dry fruits for Diwali, and the rates quoted by the first shopkeeper were like, rupees eight hundred per kilogram for almonds, and rupees six hundred per kilogram for cashews. I thought that was a bit steep. Especially since last year it was around rupees six hundred and fifty for almonds.

unnormalised: I went to like, 3-4 other shops in the market. Believe it or not, one guy was selling the same almonds for Rs 750/kg! And another was quoting ₹620 for cashews. It's crazy how much the price fluctuates within the same market! I ended up getting them for Rs. 720 & ₹580 respectively from the last shop I checked. Always pays to bargain and compare prices in the Indian markets, doesn't it?
normalised: I went to like, three or four other shops in the market. Believe it or not, one guy was selling the same almonds for rupees seven hundred and fifty per kilogram! And another was quoting rupees six hundred and twenty for cashews. It's crazy how much the price fluctuates within the same market! I ended up getting them for rupees seven hundred and twenty and rupees five hundred and eighty respectively from the last shop I checked. Always pays to bargain and compare prices in the Indian markets, doesn't it?

unnormalised: Moral of the story: always, always bargain. You can usually get a discount of at least 5-10% if you’re good at it. And don't be afraid to walk away if they’re not budging on the price. There are usually plenty of other vendors selling similar stuff nearby. Happy shopping, and happy Diwali in advance!
